rule.name: Do not use empty Catch Blocks
rule.description:
Empty catch blocks are a poor design. Always output an error and use error handling in the event of an exception.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not invoke non constant members
rule.description:
Using variable member invocations can result in an empty invocation from occurring. This can result in undesired circumstances.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use special characters in method names
rule.description:
The use of special characters in method names can result in parser errors when executing the script.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use reserved words as parameter names
rule.description:
Exceptions and unwanted bahaviour occurs when reserved words are used as paramater names.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Functions that use ShouldProcess sould support Force to bypass
rule.description:
In order to correctly support the force boolean switch, you need to call ShouldContinue correctly when you call ShouldProcess.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use trap statements
rule.description:
Trap statements are designed for administrators. Try Catch should be used in all written script files. History: Trap was implemented in v1, because it was all the PowerShell team had time to implement.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use unitialized variables
rule.description:
Uninitialized variables will cause script errors, and should never be used before assignment.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Incorrect precedence for comparison operator against null
rule.description:
If the item on the left hand side is an Array, PowerShell will automatically check the whole Array for null.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Use only approved verbs
rule.description:
The approved verbs are designed to describe the scope of the action, not using them can confuse the scripts intention to the end user.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Use a Byte Order Mark with non Ascii files
rule.description:
Ascii is a 7-bit to the byte encoding. Files that use UTF-8/UTF-16 or another encoding should use a byte order mark to allow identification.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Call CmdLets with correct parameters
rule.description:
CmdLets must be called with the correct syntax and parameters.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Remove unused variable
rule.description:
Variables that have been assigned but not used should be removed for better supportability in the future. Having unused variables can confuse the scripts intent.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Declare output types correctly
rule.description:
No exception will be thrown if you pass the wrong type, which can result in undesired results.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Use singular nouns for CmdLets
rule.description:
As standard practice for PowerShell, CmdLets should be named Verb-Noun in the singular form.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use Invoke-Expression
rule.description:
Invoke-Expression allows external text to be run as code. Evaluated code at runtime is a script injection vulnerability. Dynamic code can be executed using PowerShells & operator and splatting to apply the paramaters required.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Computer name switches on applicable CmdLets shouldn't be hardcoded
rule.description:
Harcoding server names in scripts can expose critical information about the target system..

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use convert to secure string
rule.description:
Converting to secure string from plain text is insecure and exposes sensative data

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use direct hardcoded file paths
rule.description:
Exposing directory structure in a script can possibly expose the layout of internal systems. This script may also not work on other machines

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use plain text for passwords
rule.description:
Using plain text passwords directly compromises your system security

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Use PSCredential type for credential parameters
rule.description:
PowerShell security best practices state that the PSCredential type should be used to secure credentials correctly. Also the CredentialAttribute has to be applied after the PSCredential attribute to be correctly parsed and secure.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Avoid Empty Help Attributes
rule.description:
Empty help attributes causes an error in execution when requested.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use depricated manifest field
rule.description:
Depricated manifest fields cause parser errors when being executed in the wrong context.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use positional parameters
rule.description:
Positional parameters increase readability of scripts allowing for better team supportability within the code.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Avoid usage of $ErrorActionPreference
rule.description:
Using $ErrorActionPreference can create some strange behaviour by purposfuly disabling errors from happening. Potential errors should be checked for with an if statement before they can happen, or be caught in a try-catch-finally.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use Write-Host
rule.description:
Write-Host is never needed in PowerShell CmdLets. Instead use the correct Write-<verb> for your situation. Write-Error for Errors, Write-Debug for debug, Write-Verbose for extra informaiton on request.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not write code in the global scope
rule.description:
Assignment to variables and usage of variables, in the global scope can cause value conflicts across scripts. It is recommended to use methods and local variables where possible.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Avoid using Backticks (`) to spread code over multiple lines
rule.description:
Backticks are used to spread lines of code in PowerShell over multiple lines. The downside is that they are difficult to see and hard to maintain and grasp a clear intent for the code structure.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Use [CmdletBinding()] with Write Verbose/Debug
rule.description:
CmdletBinding allows usage of -Verbose and -Debug switches to apply to the contents of methods in the PowerShell Script and should be applied where Write-Verbose or Write-Debug CmdLets are used.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not use CmdLet Aliases
rule.description:
Do not use CmdLet aliases with the exceptions of "cat", "cp", "curl", "diff", "echo", "kill", "ls", "man", "mount", "mv", "ps", "pwd", "rm", "sleep", "tee", "type", "wget" which are acceptable and whitelisted.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Do not default true switch parameter
rule.description:
Using a default value of true on a switch property will have undesired results.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Exported CmdLets should include comment help
rule.description:
Comments should be provided which supple the help context of the Exported CmdLet for use with Get-Help.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Provide verbose messaging for the end user
rule.description:
Verbose messaging can allow indepth program flow when required to the end user, allowing CmdLets to be more easily used especially in cases where an error occurs.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Follow PowerShell naming conventions for better consistency for methods
rule.description:
To show better intent of each method, consider naming methods in PowerShell with the CmdLet style naming practice of Verb-Noun.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Avoid usage of Hungarian notation
rule.description:
Hungarian notation was used extensively in the past. However it is widely seen today as confusing to read, and can hide the true intent of a program meaning that code written can become unsupportable.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: Avoid usage of inline comments
rule.description:
Inline comments are only useful when reading a script. Getting into the habbit of putting comments in a Write-Verbose or a Write-Debug can give the end user help, as well as the script reader.

See SPCAF documentation

rule.name: AliasesToExport, CmdletsToExport, FunctionsToExport and VariablesToExport should be declared either empty or with exports only
rule.description:
Incorrectly defining the exports slows down the compilers module auto-discovery task.

See SPCAF documentation
